title: T10 LED Lamp Shade (12V)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
UPDATE 6/20/12: Added Netfabb'ed versions. This is a press-fit lamp shade for inexpensive 12V 9-LED T10 automotive lamps. I believe these are sometimes called "wedge lights," and are used as turn signals or interior lights. (I got mine on ebay for $1.50 for two, shipping included.) They're made for 12V DC operation, which is convenient for reprappers, and they don't really need to be fastened to the frame if you're using solid core wire. These things are quite bright, and the shade does a great job of keeping the light in one place and not in your eyes. They require about 225mm of 3mm filament each (about a nickel). v1.0 - The original prints shade down, with no built-in support structure
v1.1 - Prints base down with extra support on the shade-to-base transition. (On left in photo printed in white.)
v1.2 - Prints shade down with simple built-in support structure. (On right in photo printed in white.)

1) Print the part. (Check description above for which version to print.)
2) Strip about 4mm of the ends of a wire (I use twisted pair from old network cable), and insert the bare wire into the holes on the side.
3) Noting which side is positive, press the bulb into the slot and be sure the wires are pressed toward the back and are not shorted.
4) Plug it into to a 12V and aim it somewhere interesting. I created this with OpenSCAD and printed it with yellow 3mm PLA withh a 5mm nozzle on a self-sourced Prusa Mendel. I had to clean up the inside a bit, but other than that it seems to work just fine. Enjoy! I need to clean up the OpenSCAD file a bit -- it was a bit of a quick hack, because I just received the lamps today -- but I'll post it when I do.

title: 1993-1997 Camaro Morimoto mini D2S square retrofit
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
All 3D printed parts needed for a 1997 Camaro HID retrofit using the Morimoto Mini D2S 3.0 square projector and the Morimoto 35w ballast. Uses the factory adjusters to aim.

The included adjustment bracket is to space the header panel down and forward; one side of my Camaro did not need this, the other did. Not sure which side is correct, I assume that my car had an accident repair at some point before I got it which is why it's different left to right.

The projector mount should be printed out of ABS or something similar, PETg won't work. I printed the light pipe cover, lens cover, adjuster bracket from ABS. The light pipe, rear cover and body mounts from PETg. Cutting templates from PLA, don't forget to label them.

Installation on car is simple enough. Assemble the springs to the projector mount, I used self-tapping screws. Then I used a pliers and cotter pins to install the springs to the body mount after the projectors were mounted. It's tricky... Also note that if you don't hold the cutting template flat the mounting holes will not line up with the body mount. I might try to make it easier, but this is a DIY thing, I'm sure you can figure it out.

The light pipes take 10 3mm LEDs, and obviously need basic knowledge about LEDs to wire them.

Other parts needed (hardware can be found at McMaster-Carr):
Glass lens. 3/16" thick, take the lens cover to a glass shop and have them cut them to fit for you.
Sealant. Either polyurethane or silicone based, something heat and UV stable.
Nylon-Insert Locknuts M5 X 0.8 mm
Nylon-Insert Locknuts M6 X 1 mm
Low-Profile Sckt Head M6 X 1 mm Thread, 16 mm Long (x8, for adjuster)
Sckt Head M5 X 0.8 mm Thread, 55 mm Long (x8)
Sckt HeadM6 X 1 mm Thread, 25 mm Long (x20)
Screws, I think they were #12 self tapping screws, 1" long. (x4)
1/8" cotter pins
Springs, extended length 77mm, I used a generic extension spring that had a compressed length of 2.5" and a spring rate of about 7lbs. (x4)

I recommend using brass or stainless steel hardware. I've got over 1000 hours into this design. Please don't remove my name from the parts.

author: Mattstrike

description.text:
Have you mice on your attic too?
And you won't slay or poison these mice?
But if you are placing a live catch trap there and you will forget it so they will starve in a long way. Also not better.

Therfore i have upgraded a live trap from amazon with a little circuit which sends via WLAN / internet a message to my telegram-bot.

(See the demonstration video here: https://youtu.be/tJTT1gJi4og)

Telegram is my preferred social app. It's easy to create a bot there for your own ideas, so it's simple to send your bot a message with an URL called by any device.

Because the attics have mostly no LAN-cable i am using the WLAN in my house. So a IOT device with WLAN is needed. I am using 'Wemos D1 mini', it costs not more than 4 dollars from china.

The genious idea of this project is, that the trap needs no current! If you are powering WLAN-chipsets to wait for closing the trap, you have to charge the batteries (AA/AAA) all 4 days.
So my idea is not to power the device at all:
Take a wooden clothespin, drill 2 thumbtacks into it and solder the plus-cable to them.
Open the clothesin and move a little plastic between the mouth. So nothing is powered.
Tie a stitch from the plastic to the moving parts of your trap.
If the trap is closing, the stitch removes the plastic, the thumbtack are connecting and the device can power up! After powering the device will register itself in your WLAN and call the URL of your telegram bot.
After this the code sets the device into a deep sleep mode, so nearly no current is needed.
Get your message, free the mouse (far away from your house :-) and move the plastic back into the clothespin.

On your device, you have to code something, so the device is calling the URL you have prepared in you social app bot. You can find my example in this package. Be aware, that you have to replace your WLAN-login data and your ids from your bot before uploading it.
For programming your WLAN device search in the net. There are many free developing tools and articles for doing this.

So have fun and be friendly to the mice :-)

Update: The first mouse is catched :-) Alive!

comments.text:
Great! In the past i made an identical solution, but I used an old mobile phone to make a call when the mouse entered in the trap, because i don't like to kill animals and also I want to avoid stress in the mouse, leaving it a lot of time in the trap! Sometimes I waked up at 3-4am to free the mouse. ;-)
The cons of my solution is that I need to leave the phone always connected to a wall charger, when a plug is available.
Your great idea is to power the device (Wemos) only when the trap closes, then put it in deep sleep.
I will update soon my trap to a Wemos version!
A very smart project to respect the nature.
Thanks!
Carlo

description.text:
This is a customisable octaedron.
You can use the customiser to pile them up as much as you want.

I just like that shape, it's fascinating how hard it is to visualise.

You can make it a vase or whatever you wish ! It's a piece of OpenScad code. Just post a make of what you did, i'm curious !

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.3

Infill:

no

Notes:

To get a nice pot out of that shape, set the infill to 0, the bottom layers to 2 and use the spiralise feature.

Here is the OpenScad code that you can copy and paste

//Octaedron Generator by David_LG 03/02/2017
// this isn't a precise model, but it seems ok for 3D printing purposes

Diameter=100; // Diameter of the circumbscribed circle
Total_Height=200; // Total Heigth
Number_of_octaedrons=3; // Total number of octaedrons to pile up

Height=Total_Height/Number_of_octaedrons;

for(i=[0:Number_of_octaedrons-1]){
rotate([0,0,60i])translate([0,0,Heighti])hull(){
cylinder(r=Diameter/2,h=.0001, $fn=3);
rotate([0,0,60])translate([0,0,Height])cylinder(r=Diameter/2,h=.0001, $fn=3);
}
}

description.text:
The Snooze button on my Westclox 22651 stopped working because I broke a little pin on the back side of the button. This spacer restores normal function of the button. Detailed repair pictures on my blog at
http://mysd300.blogspot.com/2012/04/same-day-repair.html

For a Westclox 22651 or equivalent:

  • Open the clock by removing 2 screws on the underside. (One is underneath the backup battery, if so equipped.)

  • Remove the circuit board carrying the switches by removing 3 screws securing it to the top of the clock.

  • Inspect the underside of the snooze button and any remnants of the plastic pin.

  • Replace the pin by putting your 3D-printed spacer onto the middle rib. (No glue should be necessary--the spacer will be held in the gap between the button and the circuit board.)

  • Replace the circuit board, taking care to slip it under the plastic hooks nearest the face of the clock. Replace the 3 screws and test the snooze button.

  • If everything's okay, reassemble the clock and replace the 2 exterior screws.
    • STEP file is included so you can customize it for a similar repair in a different device, in case your dimensions are different. Try printing one sample un-modified, test it in your device, measure the differences (if any), and adjust the model data.

This is an enlarged version from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:536259. Overall height is about 8 Inches (200mm). I've enlarged it greatly and turned it off it's side and separated the cup (top) from the stand (middle) and hollowed out the stand so it can be printed without supports and use less filament. Some minor filing may be required for precise fitting. The top (cup part) will still need supports but only on the inside. Avoiding supports on the outside helps keep the outside 'clean'.

I've made a slight adjustment to the middle section to make the mating hole easier to sand if needed, I've also added a solid bottom to make gluing easier.

For the creation I set the top at .1mm, the middle at .2mm and the bottom at .3mm.

For finaliziing (in the picture) I filled the middle with sand. Then I glued the top on. Then spray painted them silver, leaving the bottom unpainted. Then glued them to the bottom.

title: Ultimod By Bezain.   For an Ultimate and Perfect Discoeasy

description.text:
Voici le mod le plus complet et le plus abouti pour votre Dagoma Discoeasy.

https://www.lesimprimantes3d.fr/forum/topic/8020-le-mod-ultime-par-bezain-pour-une-discoeasy-parfaite/

Ce mod vient palier tous les défauts mineurs de cette imprimante, pour en faire une redoutable machine.
Il comporte en effet les modifications suivantes :
-Rigidification totale de la machine. Un système de triangulation, complètement réglable, vous assure non seulement le renfort par triangulation des axes Z, mais surtout ce sytème vous garantit d'etre efficace, par le réglage des vis pressions, qui vous assurent que tout l'ensemble est réellement contraint..
Le wooble disparait complètement. Les axez Z ne bougent plus d'un poil.
Par ailleurs, des logements pour tire fond ou boulons dans les pieds des renforts permettent de fixer l'imprimante à son support. Si celui ci est lourd et stable, vous gagnerez énormément en rigidité . Cela permet aussi d'abaisser le centre de gravité de l'ensemble. (Cf conseils ci dessous)
Cela permet des impressions de très grande qualité , et/ou d'imprimer plus rapidement, sans que la machine ne se mette à vibrer dans tous les sens.

-Réglage de l'orthogonalité des axes
Ces mêmes vis pressions vous permettent de corriger les défauts de non orthogonalité de la machine. Ainsi, vous obtenez des axes X,Y et Z parfaitement perpendiculaires. Cela donne au final des impressions d'une grande précision, et d'une meilleure qualité, sans réduire le temps d'impression. Le 1/10 de mm de déviation est atteignable sur 150mm de hauteur, après qq réglages.

-Réglage du nivellement du plateau. La solution soft n'est là que pour pallier les défauts de rectitude et de nivellement du plateau. Plus celui ci sera réglé correctement à la base, et moins le soft interviendra . Ce qui donne encore moins de wooble, les coupleurs des axes Z devenant quasi immobiles à chaque couche.

-Eclairage intégré par leds avec passage dissimulé des câbles dans les pieds de renfort.
celui ci est branché soit directement sur la carte, soit via un interrupteur en façade, si vous souhaitez pouvoir le commander séparément.

-L' écran est déporté, car dans mon cas cela était plus pratique et esthétique, mais avec une simple pièce support et un pistolet à colle vous pouvez le fixer sur un des pieds.

Aucune modification n'est à apporter à l'imprimante.

Impression:
Tout s'imprime sans support.
Je conseille une impression en 0.2 ou moins, un remplissage à 30%.

Matériel nécessaire:
12 écrous Nylstop diamètre M3
12 vis M3x20mm tête hexagonale
4 tire fond ou grosses vis diamètre 6 à 8, tête mini 30mm pour fixer les pieds au support.
4 barres acier ou inox diamètre 8mm, longueur 344mm
4 bandeaux Led (trouvé sur ama..on 30cm 12V, découpable, vous perdrez les 3 premières LED ce qui est parfait pour la taille des supports)
4 rondelles Grower diametre 3mm
4 rondelles plates diamètre 3mm

Pour la procédure de montage, veuillez vous référer à l'adresse suivante:

https://www.lesimprimantes3d.fr/forum/topic/8020-le-mod-ultime-par-bezain-pour-une-discoeasy-parfaite/

C'est un travail monumental que je mets gratuitement à disposition de la communauté, alors merci pour les Tips !

Bezain

description.text:
This is rev 1 of a custom modeled adapter to inflate a stand up paddleboard.

one side is a Halkey-Roberts HR style valve that I modeled by measuring the adapter. The other side is a 1/4" NPT adapter. The intention is to use a 1/4 NPT to Schrader adapter, so I can inflate the paddleboard using an air compressor.

I had previously purchased a "slingshot adapter" on Amazon, but it didn't fit my paddleboard (CBC iSUP); it wouldn't seal properly and didn't have the small beam in the center designed to keep the valve open. It was also way overpriced.

FIRST PRINT: Printed in PLA, quality isn't as high as I would like. The 1/4 NPT worked but I had to force it a bit to get it seated, and you can see where I torqued it a bit. I haven't tested it yet to inflate the board as its in the 20s outside.

The NPT adapter I used is the Milton S-684-4 1/4" NPT Tank Valve https://smile.amazon.com/gp/product/B001PLI4BA/
Here is the Lego Sword, if you want it perfect for lego mini figure make sure the handle is exactly 3.18mm in diameter.Have fun with my design for stop motions and more!

Many Thanks to- Mr Gael- for sharing his work-

This is Re-Mix of the Inmoov Head for BigBed Printers -- (230mm x 150mm Min ?)
More Updated Photos will be uploaded soon,,,,(some photos are from v2 version)

There is a fair bit of Mod work done to Interior mechanical parts but the overall design remains the same, the exterior Skull is as close to the original as could make it,,

So basically all the smaller parts where aligned then hand stitched together the largest error in the exterior Skull was less then 1mm,,, there has been Mod work on the interior Skull and the jaw has been scaled a little bit to mach the curves of his face a bit better-

All parts have been printed and tested,,, they are in there printing position and are error free,,, the use of Support material will be need for some of the parts,,,

The Gear Ratios are the same as the original inmoov and i have kept it as Backward Compatible as much as possible,,,,

The Eyes and Ears are not included- download the originals from the inmoov website or use the modded ones that are in with my other designs-- the ears will have to be downloaded from the inmoov website--

The Skull is not a easy print,,, i strongly recommend you try different slice setting to find the best one that matches your printer-- even do some test prints at half-scale will give you good idea on what setting you will need to use,,

Sketch-Up Files are included- so you Modify the parts to suit you own design

*Note --"Square M3 Nuts are used--"- Cheap ones, not the Stainless steel ones which are slightly bigger (but they can be squeezed in )
"
Mine is "0.3mm layer height" and "0.5 mm Default extrusion width " but this will Change for the final print,,,
100% infill for the low skull - around 2 perimeters
50% infill for the top Skull- around 8 perimeters,, or enough perimeters so that only perimeter lines can be seen,,

i do not recommend this project for beginners ,,,,,,,

Once again Many Thanks to "Mr Gael" Inmoovs Designer --

-=Mindless=-

Gives a nice close up of the set up thanks. I saved the images with the rest of your files.
How is the gear mounted to the servo? Is it just a round hole with a bolt threaded up against the brass shaft to hold it in place?. My servos did not come with round horns, and the splines are 17 teeth. bit abnormal. I have been trying to draw it in fusion 360. comments.author: Mindless

comments.text:
Added a pic of how I did the servo to gear mount,,,, this systems it works great but it can split the plastic if the pressure from the bolt gets is too much ,,, the bolt just pushes the Spline of the servo “into” the plastic which makes solid non-slip connection,,,
Printing a Servo Spine can be done,,, you need a 0.2mm gap between the Servo Spline and the servo spline pattern you designing ,,,,, then you need to reduce the printing- ” Layer Width to 0.35mm” and the “Layer Hight 0.1mm” This works well for me, use a ED3V6 – 0.4mm Nozzle ,, I only use Slic3r/Repetier and” Slic3r Prusa Edition” is very cool too..,, reduce printing speed for” Small Perimeters “ to 10mm/sec – Most people use Cura which is very basic bare bones Slicer that works very well,,, but you really need to reduce the Extruder” layer width” for fine work like the Servo Spline –
I mainly PLA+ (Esun at the moment)-- anyone can print in PLA+ ,,, but Printing good quality parts in PLA+ is a different story,, ,, if your printer is setup for ABS and you’re getting good prints stick with ABS don’t change,,, hope this helps

title: Magnet Beam Pulse Motor for Quarter Inch or 8mm Shaft
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a conceptual pulse motor. It uses eight repulsed magnets (north facing north) at four locations on the rotor. It is meant to run on a Bedini SSG circuit (like this one: http://www.teslagenx.com/kits/tx-sg4tub.html?category=kits) but can be used with other methods (reed switch, hall switch, commutator,). You have a choice to run the coils as air coils or you can use the spaces provided in the motor braces for iron cores (bunches of copper coated welding wire).

It is your choice whether you pick the files for the 1/4" shaft/bearing or the 8mm shaft/bearing.

For more information on this technology a good place to start should be: http://www.energyscienceforum.com/forum.php

Disclaimer: Build and experiment at your own risk. Catastrophic failure of parts spinning at high speed can cause damage to property, injury, or death.

Parts List:

X8 magnets: http://www.magnet4less.com/product_info.php?cPath=1_5&products_id=54
1/4" or 8mm shaft at around six inches in length should be enough: http://www.vxb.com/SearchResults.asp?Search=shaft
bearings for 1/4" shaft: I like to use these with some high speed oil applied: http://www.vxb.com/SR4AZZ-Stainless-Steel-Dry-1-4-x3-4-x9-32-inch-p/kit8540.htm
bearings for 8mm shaft: any 8mm X 22mm X 7mm bearing should be fine: found at any Skateboard shop or http://www.vxb.com/8mm-inner-diameter-Bearings-s/166.htm
X8 6-32 stainless steel or brass bolts for the motor brackets
You can get cheap copper coated iron welding wire from: http://www.harborfreight.com/0030-in-er70s-6-mig-solid-welding-wire-10-lb-roll-69530.html This is optional.

The circuit and wire is up to you.

description.text:
A simple bracket for holding a terratrip 101plus on the dashboard. With a small sun shield and a hinge. Can be printed as is without supports.
Need 2 M6 Nuts along with some M6 wing bolts to assemble it. And there are two 5.5mm holes on the bottom for mounting on the dashboard.

It can has 360 degree of rotational freedom with the terratrip mounted and can be locked in place by tightening the wingnuts.

Will post pictures of it mounted on the dashboard on a later date.

title: Monoprice Select mini tool holder and filament guide

description.text:
Hi. I hope you like this. it's my own personal design for a small tool holder mounted to the front of the monoprice select mini. it comes with spaces for the 4 main allen wrenches used on the printer as well as a spot for tweezers and spaces for 4 nozzles. I also added in the magic numbers for layer heights so they're always right there for you. and there's even a filament guide.

Now as a warning, the tool holder itself is 110mm x 81mm. so use caution when printing. you may want to print it without a skirt and brim. and Also if you're printing on glass or any other surface that you have held down with binder clips, you may need to pull them back a bit so your hot end doesn't hit them.

you will need 2 M3 x 8mm screws and 2 M3 nuts

That's all i can think of. i hope you enjoy this.

comments.text: I can see you are using the same e3d hot end on the same monoprice select printer that I am using.  First off, thanks for the great design, and the layer heights are very useful.  Can I ask what you retraction settings are?  It seems that no matter what fiilament I am using, I am getting significantly worse stringing than before the e3d swap.  Thanks!
comments.author: letsmakeup

comments.text: i'm using 4.0mm for retraction. you may also want to check that your cooling is at 100% with PLA. and adjust your bed and hot end temps. they may be too high. i generally run PLA between 200 - 210c depending on the brand. and my heat bed is 45 - 55c depending on the brand.

title: Extractor para motores PAP/Extractor for PAP motor

description.text:
CASTELLANO:
Este es un extractor que sirve para motores NEMA 17 o mas pequeños, para NEMA 23 hay que agrandar las dimensiones.
Es una idea básica, generada a partir de los materiales que uno tiene el la casa, así que se pueden crear muchas variantes de tamaños. La idea es tener algo pequeño para poder sacar los engranajes de los motores reciclados.
Lista de materiales:
1x tornillo M5X25
2x varilla 6mmx 60mm
8x tuerca M6
Planchuela de 3mm de espesor o mas.

Para la fabricación:
1 Tomamos las 3 planchuelas (1 abajo y dos arriba) y hacemos un agujero de 6mm a 10mm del borde izquierdo y otro igual en el borde derecho.
2 En dos de ellas generamos un tercer agujero de 4,2mm (para hacer una rosca interna). Luego estas dos planchuelas pueden ir soldadas, si gusta, para mayor robustez.
3 En la tercera planchuela hacemos otro agujero de 6mm bien centrado y luego hacemos un corte hasta llegar al agujero en uno de los costados (por ahí se desliza el eje del motor).
4 Empezar a ensamblar todas las partes prestando atención en la alineación.
5_ Comenzar a reciclar motores!

Espero que esto les sea útil.
Saludos!

ENGLISH:
This is an extractor that is used for NEMA 17 or smaller motors, for NEMA 23 you have to enlarge the dimensions.
It is a basic idea, generated from the materials one has in the house, so that many variants of sizes can be created. The idea is to have something small to get the gears out of the recycled engines.
Material's list:
1x M5X25 screw
2x rod 6mmx 60mm
8x nut M6
Plank 3mm thick or more.

For manufacturing:
1 We take the 3 planks (1 down and 2 above) and make a hole 6mm to 10mm from the left edge and another equal on the right edge.
2 In two of them we generate a third hole of 4.2mm (to make an internal thread). Then these two plates can be welded, if you like, for greater robustness.
3 In the third plate we make another hole of 6mm well centered and then we make a cut until arriving at the hole in one of the sides (there slides the axis of the motor).
4 Begin to assemble all the parts paying attention in the alignment.
5_ Start Recycling Engines!

I hope this helps.
Regards!

The Problem Solvers Fender Flute (http://problemsolversbike.com/products/fender_flute), optimized for 3D printing.

Features 8 holes, spaced 10 mm apart.

There are two versions - one for 1-1/8" steerer tubes, & one for 1" steerer tubes.

http://problemsolversbike.com/products/fender_flute

Since it's 3D printed & I couldn't design M6 threads in this piece, I used an inset in the back to hold an M6 locknut (9.91 mm across, uses a 10 mm wrench to tighten). It's designed to hold about half of the flat height, which comes out to be 2.69 mm.

I copied the 100 mm length & number of holes (8), but I didn't adhere to the 10 mm thickness & 20 mm width. Instead, I made it 7.5 mm thick.

It turns out that the ID of the steerer is 1/8" smaller than its OD (1", 1-1/8") in both cases, for which I've designed (http://www.retrobike.co.uk/forum/viewtopic.php?t=207027).

• x2 M6 bolts
  • x2 M6 nuts or locknuts

The assembly is pretty self-explanatory once you see the source image.

Stuff I might do in the future, though probably not

I was thinking, why even have discrete positions & just have a long slot? Then I remembered that front fenders have a slot anyways. It'd probably be fine with just 1 long slot + front fender slot, but oh well. Maybe I'll do that someday.

Also, this would be a cool project to parameterize/customize according to the length you need. Maybe I'll do that someday too.

2 Feb 17 If you're looking at this & thinking, "that looks a lot like a drop bolt for brakes," 1) you'd be right & 2) do NOT use it as such. It will break instantly under the massive torque of trying to stop any appreciably sized wheel spinning at any appreciable angular velocity.

http://www.sheldonbrown.com/home-drop.html

Do yourself a favor & use something like these:

  • http://handsonbike.blogspot.com/2013/09/journey-of-boardwalk-part-31-elosix.html
  • https://www.lfgss.com/conversations/214032/
Some more awesome Pepakura files converted, Cheers Jace

So this is for a specific situation. My board died and I replaced it with a Ramps 1.4. It's a lot taller and my Mini could no longer sit flat, so eschewing the base plate I made this to slide on the inside of the front and back steal plates and sit there. If you're in a situation for that, this might be for you!

UPDATE: V2 of the legs are here! Added a small lip to "help" with them sliding off once on, not sure if it truly will work yet.
Also increased the height by 1cm. For better clearance for the RAMPS board.
Lastly, decreased the space in the clip itself so it's a little tighter.

Anyway, simple addition if needed. And easy to modify, made in fusion 360. If you find the hook too loose, keep in mind that your material may contract over time, that said, lining the inside of the feet with a piece of painters tape will stiffen it up.

description.text:
Updated 2-28-2017 Updated the hookup photo to help better illustrator how to wire the probe and LM7805 to the controller board.

Updated 2-18-2017 Mathieu Fabris converted the "Marlin_firmware_How2Flash" manual to French. Available on his website:
http://www.printer3d.one/fr/tutoriel-installer-firmware-marlin-1-1-limprimante-3d-wanhao-duplicator-6/
Updated 2-9-2017 to include "Probe_Calibration.PDF" manual.

This project includes just about all the information you need to add auto-bed leveling (mesh bed leveling) to a Wanhao D6 (Monoprice Maker Select Ultimate) printer. It relies on a very recent build of Marlin 1.1.0RC-8 and an induction probe that you can wire yourself.

First off, you will need the firmware and none of this would be possible without the hardwork of Rob Mendon! He went above and beyond the call of duty on this firmware. Also, this firmware has been tested and screened for bugs as best as we could. There are many features that target the D6 specifically in this firmware, so this is not a plain vanilla Marlin port.
The souce code and how to build and install it can be found here:
https://github.com/dot-bob/Marlin/tree/Wanaho-Duplicator-6

You may also need information on how to build the latest version of Marlin firmware on your machine. The instructions are in the "Marlin_firmware_How2Update.pdf" file.

If you do not have a probe, I highly recommend sticking with a 12mm induction probe. A 12mm probe with the probe mount included in this project will not hit any part of the machine, you will loose NO build volume. Here is the one I used in this project:
12mm NPN NO 3-wire 4mm Tubular Inductive Proximity Sensor Switch LJ12A3-4-Z-BX
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B008DG9FLS

I have included an 18mm probe mount as well. You WILL lose about 10mm of build volume on both the X and Y axis, but only at the extreme upper right corner. I only recommend this size probe if you have a glass buildplate or other thicker build plate materials. I used a capacitive sense probe. These probes are not as near as repeatable as the induction probe but they do work with thick glass. Here is a probe that I have tested:

18mm Approach Sensor Cylindrical Capacitive Proximity Switch PNP NO, 1-10 mm
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B008MU0CCG

Upon assembling your 12mm probe, you will see a picture of a probe with a 21mm measurement indicated. You want the probe to be mounted with 21mm past the base of the mount. This will put your probe within 1mm of the build plate. You can then fine tune the exact probe offset in the firmware under Z-Offset.

Once you build your mount, you will need to wire it up. Look at the enclosed pictures of using a 7805 voltage regulator to limit the voltage going to the Z_MIN pin.

Now that you have your probe all wired up, you need to install it on your machine. Follow the "Self_Made_Probe_Mounting.pdf" on how to install the probe on your machine and which pins you can get power for your probe and where to plug in the probe connector.

Lastly, when configuring your Marlin build for auto-bed leveling, you will need to know the probe offsets. You use the front side mount with a 12mm probe. If you have a 18mm probe, you will use the back side mount. Here are the offset for those two mounts:

// Front side Mount -- 12mm Probe offsets
;#define X_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 35 // X offset: -left +right [of the nozzle]
;#define Y_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER -15 // Y offset: -front +behind [the nozzle]
;#define Z_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 0 // Z offset: -below +above [the nozzle]
*/
// Back side Mount -- 18mm Probe offsets
;#define X_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 35 // X offset: -left +right [of the nozzle]
;#define Y_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 52 // Y offset: -front +behind [the nozzle]
;#define Z_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 0 // Z offset: -below +above [the nozzle]

If you need any information on Marlin configuration, it is hard to beat this source which explains everything and what each setting does/means:
http://marlinfw.org/docs/configuration/configuration.html

After you install the probe, now you need to calibrate the probe height to the build plate. This is covered step by step in the Probe_Calibration_Updated.PDF. It also included the required G-code that needs to be added to your existing slicer starting script.

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator 6

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

75%

Notes:

I print my mounts in ABS. You might be able to use PETG as well, but PLA will sag as the probe mount is very close to the heater block.

I only recommend ABS. Print at 66% or higher infill. I printed some at 75% infill and other at 66% infill. The more solid the mount, the better.

When printing ABS, I recommend 101% scale. This will counter act the ABS shrinkage. The tolerances on this part are pretty tight, so it WILL make a difference!

Check fit before installing!

The overhand, even though it is small, needs to be near perfect. It is a tight fit, so if there is not exactly 8mm between the lip and the base, you need to sand/file until there is. Especially if the support left any nubs or plastic behind when removed.

Mount modifications are possible!

I have included the 123d Design files, though if you change any part of this design, the offsets and/or the pre-calibration distance will no longer be valid.

comments.text: Thanks so much for the great info. I don't understand how the shown circuit with the 7805 possibly could work with an NPN sensor open or closed. Upon triggering an NPN would change connection between black and brown (+). There will be no signal on the 7805 input. PNP will work as the the connection will be between black and  blue (-) and you get a signal and 5V out. This is how my Omron NPN NO sensor 653-(E2BM12KN08WPC12M) behaves  and it doesn't work of course. I tried the Omron  E2BM12KS08WPB1 2M which is PNP and it works flawlessly indeed with the 7805 wiring shown and the PNP Configuration.h. This probe has a working distance of 8mm in a M12 form factor.

comments.text: Here's the big question - does it print any better than it did? Does the firmware crash less often?
comments.author: 1bigpig

comments.text: I have not had the firmware crash on me once.  As far as printing better, this is what an early tester reported back to me: "Also an interesting side effect with this firmware. My gcode that i'm mass printing with on my printer took 6.5hr prior and now takes 5hr. I had a feeling that the original firmware was limiting printer speed (my cura settings were 150/sec) and I guess this now confirms it. Nice speed up! "
comments.author: kritter

comments.text: So I'm clear, this replaces the use of the microswitch in the rear for finding Z0? Does the updated firmware also use it for automatic platform calibration; no more diddling with the three thumb screws?
comments.author: chriscook

comments.text: Yes, the probe takes the place of the Z-MIN limit switch.  The new Marlin firmware DOES support auto-bed leveling--no more messing with leveling the bed (within reason)--but as of right now, you have to build a version of Marlin with the auto-bed leveling turned on.  Once that is done, you run a start script that includes a G28 to home your machine and then G29 to auto-bed level.  Then your part file.  This will compensate for any irregularities in the bed leveling as it prints.

I designed this Little Whistle several years ago. Somehow I just never got around to posting it on Thingiverse. It is one of the first things I designed specifically for 3D printing. I use it for 3D printing demonstrations. It seems to me to be an excellent object for a 3D printing demo. It prints fast enough (about 8 minutes) that it can finish printing while someone is standing there watching. Then you can hand them something they just saw printed and it works! I have had students get a whistle at an open house before they took my class. They return after graduation and say they still had their whistle! So much more impact than watching five minutes (a couple of layers) of a two hour print.

So please enjoy this Little Whistle and whenever you get a chance to show someone how a 3D printer works I hope you will print them a whistle (especially the kids). Perhaps it will help spark an interest for the next generation of Makers!

Disclaimer - Not for small children. Choking Hazard!!!!**

Chuck

P.S. Remember there is a fine line between a whistle and a hyperventilator!

Edit 2-4-16:
I saw that I had uploaded the wrong STL file for the whistle with loop so I fixed that.

I also uploaded the original Little Whistle that did not have a lanyard loop. It will print slightly quicker.

I also uploaded one with a revised lanyard loop. I had met Cudacountry at a maker event and he came up with the more integrated lanyard loop so props to him. He has a nice web page with lots of Solidworks tutorials and projects so check it out. http://www.cudacountry.net/html/solidworks_toc.html

I created this for a customized Nerf Roughcut. I had spare time, wanted extra ammo storage, and created this. Credit to waltherion and AMS3000 for the original files.

UPDATE 2/22/2017- The dart holders might be a bit too tight for some users and darts. I recommend sanding them down. I also plan on uploading a version with wider holes, but this obviously will not be an immediate update.

I would also appreciate it if you post a Make if you have downloaded and printed this creation. Even just commenting an Imgur link to your print is appreciated.

I have also been told that this was marked as Adafruit's "3D Print of the Week." Thanks guys!

Screws The original creator of the dart holder, Waltherion, says that he recommends "M2.6x8mm Phillips Drive Flat Head Self-Tap Electronic Screws." You will need 4. However, I managed to find something small enough lying around in my garage, so who knows.

title: 3 Point Leveling Bed Carriage for 12" bed plate
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This 3 point leveling bed carriage is meant to accept Misumi LMUW8 linear bearings (or equivalent) which you press into the open shafts in the corners. These linear bearings ride on 8mm linear shafts for z axis travel. The center accepts a nut for an 8mm lead screw.

To implement this setup you need to print two of these carriages.

To properly use the 3 point leveling provided by these carriages you form opposing triangles with your hardware such that one triangle tightens the bed down towards the carriages while the other three bolts/screws simply provide support after leveling has been achieved by the other set of three that clamp the bed down. See my pictures for clarification.

The springs I'm using in the pictures to support the 1/4" MIC 6 plate are McMaster part number 9657K311

Main hardware is M3 size bolts

Works very well with my belted linked lead screw drive: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2063609

Original bed carriage idea was developed by Maks Zolin for the Voron CoreXY project.
https://github.com/mzbotreprap/VORON

title: 10 Ways to Impress Your Lover Window Decals

description.text:
These are fun, easy prints that take up just a tiny amount of filament. One of the cool features of a soft flexible like NinjaFlex (SH=85A) is that it sticks really well to windows and mirrors when printed at 1mm to 3mm thickness. It's important that your print surface and the windows you stick the decals on are clean ;) to insure smooth against smooth. Just wet with water and stick. I have some up in my office that have been there for almost a year. If you don't have any flexible filament you can buy some magnets at a craft store and turn these into refrigerator magnets. I started with images downloaded from pixabay.com from their public domain section and edited them for printing.

I create these designs to encourage people to try out flexible filaments or get some new interesting colors of flexibles. For info on purchasing samples of several brands of flexible filament see flexyfilament.com

You might like these other decals I designed on Thingiverse:

Problem Solvers Braze-On Light Mount (http://problemsolversbike.com/products/braze_on_light_mount) adapted for 3D printing.

Ideal for sticking a light anywhere you have a braze-on on your frame. Has to be a standard 4 mm threading. Would be great for the midblade fork braze-ons on a ton of Surly forks.

http://problemsolversbike.com/products/braze_on_light_mount General dimensions came from here. I had to guess for a lot of it, but it's probably okay.

For the cylinder ID, I did a 6 mm offset from the OD, so that gives a 32 - 6 = 26 mm ID. The mating faces of the end caps were designed with a radius of (32-3)/2-1, so a 27 mm ID, plus a 1 mm by 1 mm 45 degree chamfer to better tolerate the fitting. The inside of the cylinder has a 45 deg chamfer on both ends as a transition between the 32 mm OD & the 26 mm ID, again to better tolerate the fit.

I hope it works.

I measured the OD of a random 4 mm socket head bolt I had lying around: 8.90 mm, so 115% of that is about 10.22 mm, which became the inset on the end of the end cap to sink the head. The head was 5.09 mm tall, but I tried to keep the cap relatively short, so I cut it from the end to the 2.5 mm from the inside face, giving about a total of 5.34 mm of sinking height. It should shelter most 4 mm socket bolt heads below the outside edge.

See the Problem Solvers website linked above for instructions.

Reverse the end cap to change the effective length of mount as necessary.

You'll need a very long 4 mm bolt.

Print all three pieces: cylinder, reversible end cap, end cap.

remixed_from.title: Flexing battery holders with integrated spring

description.text:
Evolution of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2049102.
I created a base to fit all the electronics gear and added a couple of buttons to control the program, as well as AAA batteries and a power switch.

Still a work in progress.

https://youtu.be/TtQbw61offs

Re-used...

The cover and scaffold pieces from: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2049102

Also printed...

One of the AAAx4 versions of the battery holders at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:456900 and wired it in. I added a power switch to the positive wire in order to be able to keep the battery disconnected most of the time.

IMPORTANT NOTE: I can only use rechargeable batteries, and not alkaline. Alkaline batteries have a higher voltage, and 4 AAA alkaline batteries may destroy the NeoPixel LEDs used in this project.

This is actually optional. The whole thing could work without batteries altogether.

I tend to have a 5v power supply plugged into the Arduino's power outlet, which turns everything on whether or not the power switch is in the off position.

I soldered cables onto my buttons so they could be placed in the intended externally accessible location, away from the breadboard. They are held in place from behind with the same kind of screws as I use to fasten the different plastic pieces together Placed the Arduino, breadboard, battery holder, power switch, and buttons into the base's bottom. Removed the cover and scaffold from the old base. Attached the old scaffold to the new lid... Re-attached the cover, and connect the wires to the breadboard. Place the lid back on and voila, it's all covered up. Program

The current version of the program does not need the NeoMatrix library (still needs the NeoPixel library), does use the apex LED, and can be controlled by the buttons, like this:

Normally, the buttons allow changing the program modes (there are only two right now: rainbow, and single color) while the colors cycle automatically.

If you press both buttons, the color will stop cycling automatically and now using the two buttons will allow you to select the color. Pressing both buttons again returns to the previous behavior.

Lessons Learned

  • Perhaps as a result of the print being curled up at the bottom, the "Arduino Bumper" part of my design was a little too snug for my Arduino which I could not fit into the hole. I should fix this in future versions, widening the space where the Arduino should fit. I didn't worry too much about it, yet, though; my Arduino half fits, and is held tight by pressure and friction.

  • Also, re: the "Arduino Bumper" space. I mis-measured where/how the USB and power outlets are, relative to it. This prevents the lid from closing all the way and definitely should be fixed in future versions. I haven't worried much about it yet, though, as it leaves only a 1mm gap on one side and reprinting would be relatively expensive.

  • The holes for the two buttons on the side were too narrow, and the ledge for them was too tall or perhaps unnecessary. Rather than fix in STL and reprint, I used a drill to make the holes bigger.

  • The opening for my power switch on the side of the print was a bit too wide, so the switch is only very loosely held in place. I should fix this in future versions.

  • Screwing the base pieces together would make it a pain to swap out batteries. Should think this through for future versions. I haven't worried about it too much so far because, as I mentioned, it tends to be plugged into an outlet.

This project accompanies a video tutorial on creating regular polygons in OpenSCAD. It is intended to be a lesson that uses 3d printing/ 3d design to engage a student learning about polygons.

The second set of files gives you a few options on how you may uses these.

BlocksCAD - Polygon Fun

Requirements To implement this lesson the student will need access to an installed version of OpenSCAD. OpenSCAD is available for Windows/Mac/Linux Additionally there are online versions of OpenSCAD that can be found.

There are other tools that allow graphical create of 3d objects. However, using the scripted CAD brings together the 3 domains of learning, Math, Coding and 3d Design/ Printing.

No Additional Materials are Necessary, 3D Printer and Filament would be great though.

This thing was made with Tinkercad.

Here is a version of thing:2069650 that allows one to estimate the hours of daylight during the solstices.

Models are provided for cities at Northern Latitudes of 0, 33, 42, and 51 degrees as well as a model for Rio de Janeiro at 23 degrees South Latitude. The idea for the models comes from the geomancy web site - http://www.geomancy.org/index.php/astronomy/orthographic-projections OpenSCAD code is included.

A second openSCAD program calculates projections of the 3D models onto the xy plane. DXF files are included. PNG images were also calculated and converted to a PDF file, also included. The pdf images, although distorted by projection, can be used to determine azimuths, altitudes, and daylight hours.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator (5th Generation)

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3 mm

The models shows the yearly movement of the sun in the sky. The hemisphere represents the sky, consider yourself to be looking upwards from the center of the circle that forms the base.

The arc from due east to due west represents the movement of the sun through the sky on March 21st and September 21st, the equinoxes. The arc to the north of the equinox represents the movement of the sun on June 21st, the summer solstice, and the arc to the south of the equinox represents the movement of the sun on December 21st, the winter solstice. During the year the sun takes paths between the solstices.

If the viewer is at the equator the arcs for the summer and winter solstices are of equal length as are the hours of daylight and night.

The model is marked at the base at intervals of 10 degrees. These can be used to find azimuths for the solstice sunrises and sunsets. Start at due north and count towards the east. The arc from due north to due south is also marked at 10 degree intervals. It can be used to determine the altitude of the sun at the solstices. Start at due south and count towards the north. The solstice arcs are marked at intervals of 15 degrees ( 1 hour) and the marks can be used to estimate the hours of daylight. Count the number of intervals in the whole arc.

See the geomancy web site for more information.

title: 43.33:1 Compound Planetary Gearset, NEMA 17 Mount, No Hardware

description.text:
Youtube Torque Test!

  • https://youtu.be/tgJUiEC9_-A

Demo Arm

I also designed a Demo Mount and arm for this, http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2084886

Gear Ratio

In this gearbox the gear ratio is 43.333333:1

How It Works

The function of the gearbox is when either Sun Gear #1 or Sun Gear #3 are turned, (or both at the same speed) ring gear #2 will rotate in relation to Ring Gear #1 and Ring Gear #3, so Ring Gear #2 will rotate once for every 43.3 turns of the drive sun gear.

Ring Gear #1 & #3 Should be held at the same potential to achieve the least amount of backlash.

Sun Gear #2 has no real function except to space out the planet gears to achieve more strength in the gearbox.

You will need to arrange the planet gears as shown in the above picture.

Careful!

If you spin this gearset without enclosing the rings the planet gears could skip a tooth and get out of alignment, for this reason i have included a ring that holds the ring gears closed if you don't want to print out the demo mount and demo arm.

For more similar gearboxes like this one, please check out my other Things!

Dimensions

I have included the sketch to make parts for this gearbox, this is the sketch that used to make the NEMA 17 Mount and the Crane/ Demo Mount Project, This Sketch Provides .2mm of clearance all the way around.
For those of you without a caliper, The Ring Gears are 15mm Wide and have a 1.5mm space between them,
If you choose to, you can make custom sun gears also, Gears were Designed in Fusion 360 and the Gears in Section #1 & #3 of the Design are all Module 1 with a 30 Degree Helix angle, 20 mm Wide, scaled in the "Z" Direction at .75
The Gears in Section #2 of the Design are almost Identical to those, they are module 1.11 , 20mm wide , 30 degree helix angle, scaled at .75 in the Z direction.

Other Important Info:

CAD Files??

The most recent version of this project can be downloaded in lots of different formats from this link: http://a360.co/2xBRXPW

Show Your Work!
  • Make a "make" and show everyone what you made! (make? :0) Everyone will thank you for it!

For More Cool Projects and Upgrades, Don't forget to Follow Me on Thingiverse and Subscribe to my Youtube Channel

Gear Down For What?

title: Anet A6 X-belt tensioner (tensor del eje X para anet A6) !!! WORKS GREAT!!

description.text:
VERSIÓN FINAL
FINAL VERSION

MUY IMPORTANTE: LEER BIEN LAS INSTRUCCIONES DE IMPRESIÓN.
VERY IMPORTANT: READ PRINTING INSTRUCTIONS WELL.

ESPAÑOL:

Materiales (todos vienen con la impresora):

 ·4x tornillos M3 x 30mm 
 ·4x tuercas M3
 ·2x small part
 ·1x big part

He creado este tensor para la correa del eje X y me esta dando muy buenos resultados, así que por eso lo comparto con vosotros.

INSTRUCCIONES DE IMPRESIÓN:

 ·BIG PART: recomiendo un relleno del 100% porque debe aguantar la tensión. Subiré dos versiones, LA VERSIÓN 1 es la que aparece en las fotos, y habría que cortarle un trozo de 30mm en una barra lateral para que no golpee el cable del extrusor. LA VERSIÓN 2 es mas actualizada y mas rígida, y no requiere ninguna modificación.

 ·SMALL PART: Debe colocarse con los hexágonos en la parte superior y añadirle soporte. 
   VERSIÓN 1: ES IMPORTANTE PARA QUE ENCAJEN LAS TUERCAS, APLICAR UNA EXPANSION HORIZONTAL DE -0,3mm DENTRO DE LOS AJUSTES DE PERÍMETRO EN CURA (no sabría decir para otros programas... :$ ).
   VERSIÓN FINAL: Está actualizada y no requiere ningún ajuste de perímetro.

ENGLISH (sorry for my English level):

Materials (all included with the printer): 

 ·4x screws M3 x 30mm 
 ·4x nuts M3
 ·2x small part
 ·1x big part

I´ve created this X-belt tensioner, and because it´s bringing me good results, I decided to post it for all Anet A6 users.

PRINTING ISTRUCTIONS:

 ·BIG PART: I recommend an 100% infill because it must withstand the tension. I upload 2 versions, THE VERSION 1 is the one at the pictures, and must be modified cutting it a 30mm piece of one side bar. THE VERSION 2 is more actualized and stronger, and doesn't require any mod.

 ·SMALL PART: it must be placed with the two hexagons on the upper part and add support. 
   VERSION 1: IT´S IMPORTANT TO FIX NUTS, TO APPLY AN HORIZONTAL EXPANSION OF -0,3mm ON THE PERIMETER SETTINGS OF CURA (I don´t know in other programs... :$ ).
   FINAL VERSION: It´s actualized and doesn't requires any perimeter setting.

Anet A6

Doesn't Matter

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

100%

Para conseguir la máxima tensión, recomiendo tensar lo máximo posible la correa con los tornillos en la posición mas baja, y después apretarlos.

To get the maximum tension, I recommend tightening as much as possible the belt with the screws in the lowest position, and then tightening them.

Hey kid, if I had a junk like this Anet printer, to adjust the belt, I would simply file slots instead of the holes where the X motor bolts are in order to be able to slide the motor. This is one of the way it is done in the industry.
A better approach is like it is done on the Geeetech and others (some guy did a similar thing for the Anet), a U shape holding the idler pulley, one screw in line with the belt, one nut that I replaced by a butterfly nut to be able to easily measure the belt tension while adjusting it. author: TATTOOQAC

description.text:
This is the smallest printable tracked base I was able to print reliably.
It is designed as two independent mirrored halves, each one hosting it's reduction gearing, motor, etc.
The only vitamins you need are motors and 4mm threaded rods, the rest is all printed or filament.
The motors are the round type found in most CD-ROM/DVD-ROM drives to close/open the tray, so get your old drives and find a matching pair :) Important: keep the small screws keeping the motor in place you will need them.
It's all designed in Blender so you get the .blend file for now, I'll add stl's at a later point.

You'll find two layers in the .blend file on the first you will find an assembled half, on the seconds you will find all parts laid out and grouped for printing. They are arranged as I have printed them on my Prusa, feel free to rearange for your size. To print as select a part group, export to STL, netfabb the STL, slice. I have a 0.35 nozzle and printed them at 0.25 mm getting a theoretical layer width of 0.39 (as indicated by Slic3r). As I have setup the gear distances based on these facts and by measuring the actual gears, well YMMV. There are more gears laid out than you'll need, print them all. This is due to their real small sizes so if you print smaller quantities they will not print very well. I used 20 mm/s perimeters, 10 mm/s small perimeters, 40mm/s infill at 180 degrees to print the gears (first layer at 185). For the case 40 mm/s perimeters, 20 small perimeter, 60 infill 185/195 degrees. As pins for the small gears I used 1.75 mm filament pieces, you should be safe with anything smaller or equal to 2mm. Same is used for connecting the track links. You will need about three track links sets printed as I have them laid out or two if you add more rows, for each side 30 links are needed. I have used soft PLA for my tracks but they should be fine with normal PLA too. For the output gear and track pulleys I used 4mm threaded rod and (embedded ) nuts, this make sure everything stays in place. This is still a WIP though I'm pretty happy with it for now. Cheers! Update! Added stl files. So to print you will need (so far): 1 x case_side_1.stl
1 x case_side_2.stl
4 x drive_wheel.stl
4 x idler_wheels.stl
2 x gear_set.stl
64 x track_link.stl Vitamins: 2 x 125mm 4mm threaded rod
2 x 45mm 4mm threaded rod
2 x cdrom motors (mine are Mitsumi R-14 1425)
26 x 4 mm nuts I think that's it ... UPDATE: Due to changes in all Slic3r version after 0.72b the gears will not slice with newer versions. It turns out 0.72b has a "bug" allowing the gears to slice, I disagree but I'm not a developer. Interestingly enough Cura slices them without trouble ... So for the gears to print properly use Slic3r 0.72b or Cura. I'm marking this one as done as no further development will happen on this design. Added pictures of the final working tank :) Youtube later ...

comments.text: Good job, now I've got something to do with all the dead optical drives I have.  I did however want to point out that the prints in your pictures appear under-extruded. This may have been intentional to save filament while prototyping but if not, I would suggest you calibrate your extruder or bump up your extrusion multiplier a bit.

I've got a Kodama Trinus printer -- and it's great, but needs a little help in a few places. In particular, the print head cabling desperately needs some stress relief near the processor board. I printed another cable support design on Thingiverse (Afro3dPrinter's design https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2072628), but it just wasn't stiff enough for my taste -- so here's my considerably beefier take on things.

This design is just short enough to print on a Trinus, if you orient it diagonally on the print bed. It installs between the processor and the two Z-axis linear actuators (just snap it in place, you don't need to unscrew or loosen anything), with the little lobes on its ends facing down and hooking on two of the bolts that attach the processor to the actuators.

Features in work:
1) This design includes two holes so you could zip-tie the cabling to it -- but I'm not sure yet that they're really necessary.
2) I've now beveled the edges of the semi-cylinder that hold the cabling (out of an abundance of caution w.r.t. fraying the cables).
Hard at work
How it'll print -- upside-down from how you'll use it.

remixed_from.author: droftarts
remixed_from.title: Parametric pulley - lots of tooth profiles

title: Anet A8 GT2 Belt Pulley Insert

description.text:
UPDATE 2/6/17: I am working on a pulley that has sides to help keep the pulley centered. Having difficulty getting it to print without the first layer on top messing up the teeth. May split it into two pieces that you will need to line up and glue onto the bearing. I have heard comments on the Anet facebook group that people are having issues with the belt going to one side on long Y movements. Please note this is a setup issue. You need to check either A) that the belt holder on your Y bed is centered in relation to the pulley and B) that your pulley mount is not pulling to one side. This is more of an issue for those using Y tensioners like the one I'm using. The solution to this is to shim the pieces that the pulley mounts to. You can print a shim (I'll create a STL this evening) or just use something like a business card and puch a 3mm hole through it to shim until it is pulling level.

UPDATE: I had the wrong STL uploaded... was printing a 9.5mm inner diameter. Updated to the correct size! STL is set to 10.5mm inner diameter, should print at about 10.0 or 10.1. Let me know if it is fitting too tight, or too loose and I can upload different versions to suit your printer's needs since the tolerances are very small for this. If you don't get good looking teeth, or if it is too tight lower your extrusion rate first! Make sure you print SLOW!! 15mm/sec!!!

This will allow you to converted the smooth "pulley" (two bearings pressed against each other) to a real toothed pulley to reduce X and Y axis vibration and noise.

A toothed belt should never ride on a smooth surface, especially under tension. This allows you to use the stock bearings, no modifications at all and still have a toothed pulley. Whether you are using the stock Y and X idler mount, or a upgraded Y or X tensioner, this is a must have to ensure your belt lasts long, reduces noise from the teeth chattering on the bearing/pulley.

Thanks to droftarts for the customizer and original part!

author: poor_red_neck

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/93KBM5Px301

OpenSCAD_Linkages_Library

OpenSCAD library to create multiple types of mechanical linkages in 2D and 3D.

Thingiverse Thing: 2081445

Check out on GitHub

Check out http://machineree.com/#openscad for more information and projects.

v.02 - February 5, 2017

  • linkages.scad: 2D & 3D linkages in one library

    • Added help function: linkagehelp();
    • Added linkwidthangle, linksurroundangle in 2D & 3D for angled flat bar linkages with 2/3 holes
    • Renamed modules to fit scheme
    • Changed slots in linkwidth & linksurround to true/false
    • scale(in()) for inches
    • scale(cm()) for centimeters

v.01 - January 31, 2017

  • linkages.scad: 3D Linkages
  • linkages2D.scad: 2D Linkages to be exported .SVG or .DXF
  • linkageex.scad: examples of some of the operations and functions of the library

Add to your library folder in OpenSCAD and use the include function to begin using these modules.

include <linkages.scad>

OpenSCAD Libraries (Manual)

Default units are mm.

3D Linkages

  1. linkwidth(holeD,width,length,thick,slot=false);

    • holeD: diameter of the holes at each end
    • width: width of the part (must be greater than holeD)
    • length: distance between outer holes from center
    • thick: thickness of the part or Z value
    • slot: true for a slot

  2. linkwidththree(holeD,width,length,thick,three);

    • holeD: diameter of the holes at each end
    • width: width of the part
    • length: distance between outer holes from center
    • thick: thickness of the part or Z value
    • three: distance a third hole is from the first hole, choose length/2 for center hole

  3. linkwidthrot(holeD,width,length,thick,rot);

    • holeD: diameter of the holes at each end
    • width: width of the part
    • length: distance between outer holes from center
    • thick: thickness of the part or Z value
    • rot: angle of rotation for the second hole to create angular linkages

  4. linkwidthangle(holeD,width,length1,length2,thick,angle);

    • holeD: diameter of the holes at each end
    • width: width of the part (must be greater than holeD)
    • length1: distance between holes from center, first section
    • length2: distance between holes from center, angled/second section
    • thick: thickness of the part or Z value
    • angle: angle of second section referenced from first section

  5. linksurround(holeD,surround,length,thick,slot=false);

    • holeD: diameter of the holes at each end
    • surround: distance from the edge of the hole to the edge of the part
    • length: distance between outer holes from center
    • thick: thickness of the part or Z value
    • slot: true for a slot

  6. linksurroundthree(holeD,surround,length,thick,three);

    • holeD: diameter of the holes at each end
    • surround: distance from the edge of the hole to the edge of the part
    • length: distance between outer holes from center
    • thick: thickness of the part or Z value
    • three: distance a third hole is from the first hole, choose length/2 for center hole

  7. linksurroundrot(holeD,surround,length,thick,rot);

    • holeD: diameter of the holes at each end
    • surround: distance from the edge of the hole to the edge of the part
    • length: distance between outer holes from center
    • thick: thickness of the part or Z value
    • rot: angle of rotation for the second hole to create angular linkages

  8. linksurroundangle(holeD,surround,length1, length2,thick, angle);

    • holeD: diameter of the holes at each end
    • surround: distance from the edge of the hole to the edge of the part
    • length1: distance between holes from center, first section
    • length2: distance between holes from center, angled/second section
    • thick: thickness of the part or Z value
    • angle: angle of second section referenced from first section

2D Linkages

  1. linkwidth2D(holeD,width,length,slot=false);

    • holeD: diameter of the holes at each end
    • width: width of the part (must be greater than holeD)
    • length: distance between outer holes from center
    • slot: true for a slot

  2. linkwidththree2D(holeD,width,length,three);

    • holeD: diameter of the holes at each end
    • width: width of the part
    • length: distance between outer holes from center
    • three: distance a third hole is from the first hole, choose length/2 for center hole

  3. linkwidthangle2D(holeD,width,length1,length2,angle);

    • holeD: diameter of the holes at each end
    • width: width of the part (must be greater than holeD)
    • length1: distance between holes from center, first section
    • length2: distance between holes from center, angled/second section
    • angle: angle of second section referenced from first section

  4. linksurround2D(holeD,surround,length,slot=false);

    • holeD: diameter of the holes at each end
    • surround: distance from the edge of the hole to the edge of the part
    • length: distance between outer holes from center
    • slot: true for a slot

  5. linksurroundthree2D(holeD,surround,length,three);

    • holeD: diameter of the holes at each end
    • surround: distance from the edge of the hole to the edge of the part
    • length: distance between outer holes from center
    • three: distance a third hole is from the first hole, choose length/2 for center hole

  6. linksurroundangle2D(holeD,surround,length1,length2,angle);

    • holeD: diameter of the holes at each end
    • surround: distance from the edge of the hole to the edge of the part
    • length1: distance between holes from center, first section
    • length2: distance between holes from center, angled/second section
    • angle: angle of second section referenced from first section

Naming Strategy:

link+(width/surround)+(three/rot/angle)+(2D)

Examples!

Using basic linkwidth and the slot:

include <linkages.scad>

linkwidth(2,5,20,1);

translate([7.5,0,0]) linkwidth(2,5,20,1,slot=true);

Comparison of linkwidth to linksurround with the same values in mm:

include <linkages.scad>

linkwidth(2,5,20,1);

translate([15,0,0]) linksurround(2,5,20,1);

Using basic linkwidththree to determine custom distance to middle hole using a specific number or dividing by length used for the linkage:

include <linkages.scad>

linkwidththree(2,5,20,1,4);

translate([7.5,0,0]) linkwidththree(2,5,20,1,20/2);

Using linkwidthrot for complicated angled/twist linkages, using positive and negative degrees:

include <linkages.scad>

linkwidthrot(2,5,20,1,45);

translate([7.5,0,0]) linkwidthrot(2,5,20,1,-45);

translate([15,0,0]) linkwidthrot(2,5,20,1,90);

Using linkwidthrot and 90 degree linkages with flat sides. This is accomplished by making the height value the same as the width value. For linksurroundrot the height would have to be holeD+surround+surround. This is the result:

include <linkages.scad>

linkwidthrot(2,5,20,5,90);

Using linkwidthangle to create flat angled linkages, using different length segments, positive and negative angles:

include <linkages.scad>

linkwidthangle(2,5,20,20,1,45);

translate([15,0,0]) linkwidthangle(2,5,20,40,1,-90);

Comparison of scaling the same linkage in inches, centimeters, and millimeters:

include <linkages.scad>

scale(in()) linkwidth(.25,.5,3,.125);

translate([15,0,0]) scale(cm()) linkwidth(.25,.5,3,.125);

translate([22.5,0,0]) linkwidth(.25,.5,3,.125);

Simple 2X Pantograph displaying pieces, colors, and wireframe:

include <linkages.scad>

range=12;
thick=1;

color("red")
linkwidththree (1,2,range,thick,range/4);
color("blue")
translate([range/2,range/4,0])linkwidththree (1,2,3*range/4,thick,range/4);
color("yellow")
translate([0,range/4,thick]) rotate([0,0,-90]) linkwidth(1,2,range/2,thick);
color("green")
translate([0,range,thick]) rotate([0,0,-90]) linkwidththree (1,2,range,thick,range/2);



Output of help within OpenSCAD console:

include <linkages.scad>

linkagehelp();

title: Crusader GT2 200 SJCAM M10+ and RX Antenna Holder

description.text:
If you call a Diatone Crusader GT2 and a SJCAM M10+ your own then you're right here!

This little boxy mount gives you a nice and clean way to mount your M10+ with just two cable ties on top of the hood of the GT2.

The 6 Blocks on the underside of the part have a snuggly fit in the slots of one of the top plates delivered with the GT2, so its a really tight and strong fit with a really low weight.

On the back of this "backpack" I added two 4.2 mm holes to stick some PTFE tube I had layin around in for the RX antennas - (in my case its an frSky d4r II, but anyone with 2 antennas should fit, if you can tape it under the hood).

There are also two lugs on each side with a perfect fit for one of the Diatone velcro straps, also delivered with the GT2, so you can really easily strap your cam on the mount.

Right now this mount adds 7° to the angle of the hood, so its not the highest angle overall, maybe around 20°-ish. You can send me a comment and I will make some different angled versions, or a gopro session fit, or without the rx antenna holder, or.. or.. or.. you name it.

Any comments, tips, hates, whatever are really appreciated, thank you!

Printer:

Tevo Tarantula

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

30%

Notes:

The 6 Blocks are the only thing on the printplate, so you have to print a really good support structure under it, so it prints well. I used Simplify 3D with 40% support infill and it did quite well.

title: Y-axis LM08UU holder for standard Prusa i3 frame

description.text:
I noticed I can never get the printbed holder totally flat, because the linear bearings never fall into the frame holes perfectly, so there was always some tension and/or play.

This one has some lef-right plays, so you can adjust its location perfectly.

I drew this as an exercise and haven't printed and tested it yet. The thing (you need to print 3) bolts into the frame holes that were ment for zip ties. The zip ties then go through holes in the thing, and around lm08.

If anyone has some spare time and is interested in this solution, please print it and report if it works.

title: Minimal In-Line Fidget Spinner
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
My children wanted to play with a fidget spinner I'd printed from here but it was too big for their little hands so I set out to design the smallest one possible. These are the commonly used 608 bearings. The two outer bearings snap into place, just make sure you support the arm it's on while fitting. The middle one is held in by friction and a small lip on the underside. It also has the benefit of using very little material so it's ideal for short leftover filament.

UPDATE: Added files: In_Line_Spinner_V2. It's more of a simple revision than another version. I've just knocked the inner corners off the snap pegs to make fitting easier and reduce the risk of breaking them while fitting. I've left the original files for reference.

If you like this one, take a look at my Double Decker version.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

100%

Notes:

I printed with 100% infill for maximum strength on the arms and snaps but I'm sure you could get away with less. It only took 15 minutes however to print at 100% infill so why not?

Depending on your slicing software, you may have some slight stringing to tidy up on the inner edges of the out pegs.

Snap the two outer bearings in place. If you have shielded bearings like the ones pictured, you will want to make a small modification to the middle one: Remove the shields, clean the bearing thoroughly and then lube with PTFE spray or similar. There are plenty of online tutorials of how to do this.
Designed in Sketchup

Minimal Fidget Tri - Spinner
Double Decker Fidget Spinner
Speedy Car Fidget Spinner

comments.text: One of the first OpenSource that I was able to print off a working Fidget Spinner. I made two of them and my friend's children loved them;
comments.author: Mycheal

comments.text: The two outer bearings are 608. What is the inner bearing?
comments.author: superjamie

comments.text: All three bearings are 608's. The only difference with the middle one is that I have removed shields, cleaned out the grease and lubed it with PTFE spray to reduce friction.
comments.author: superjamie

comments.text: Any advice on best way to clean out the factory grease?
comments.author: csj2k

comments.text: Odorless Mineral Spirits from any hardware store will dissolve all the grease in about an hour.  Use a glass jar for the cleaning, though, not plastic.  Then, if you have an air compressor, pinch the middle and blow it clean and watch it spin!  You can then add a drip of sewing machine oil (I use high speed yo-yo bearing lube) to lubricate.  Even dry, it will spin very long.  Also, without shields and no lube, it will minimize any dirt pickup (too much lubrication will attract dirt).  When it starts making racket, pop it out and dip it in the mineral spirits for a few minutes again.
comments.author: sygyzy

comments.text: I use isopropyl alcohol. After removing the shields, I put the bearing(s) in a small tub and cover with alcohol. Put the lid on and give it a good shake for five minutes or so and that's pretty much it. You can also use an all-purpose cleaner and I've heard that ones with orange oil in them are particularly good as they contain terpene. Also, if you search youtube for "cleaning skateboard bearings"  you will find several different methods. If you end up using any chemicals, don't skip reading their safety labels.
comments.author: sygyzy

comments.text: Cool thanks for the detailed and helpful reply. I took your advice and removed the caps off two of my bearings. I put some orange cleaner used for degreasing bike parts, along with the bearings, into an ultrasonic cleaner. Then I rinsed them off and let them dry then put some lube into them. The bearings I had also weren't packed with grease, the way I see many bearings described. They really had minimal oil, like yours. I do think the cleaned and re-lubed bearings spin longer now but that might just be a bad memory.
comments.author: csj2k

comments.text: You're welcome. I also thought that the difference after cleaning the lightly oiled bearings was minimal. I did a very unscientific comparison between cleaned and not with a stopwatch but it was still difficult to tell because of not being able to give both bearings precisely the same amount of spin. If I was really concerned I could set up an aparatus to do a proper comparison but I concluded that they were at least as good and left it at that.
comments.author: sygyzy

comments.author: djeaton

comments.text: Thank you for your kind comment. If you design yourself, feel free to use the included files to add an extra arm. I've designed a tri-spinner version and plan on publishing it soon but a few refinements are needed first when I can find the time.
comments.author: djeaton

comments.text: I took the approach of encasing the center bearing with a ring like you did and then having posts like bearing covers have for the outside bearings. The center bearing caps screw in and are intended to be glued as well. I plan on adding glue to the connections to the outer bearings as well. The reason for this is that I went tiny. I mean really, really tiny. I am using 5x8x.5mm bearings. You can put three of them inside a standard skate bearing. LOL The entire spinner is 1.5" in diameter and .2" thick. Even at a 80% infill and adding the bearing covers for the center bearing, it is less than 1.5G of filament per unit. They are for the little guys. At slightly larger than a quarter, they are hopefully too big to swallow. But with a 3/4 inch spin radius, the kids should love them. Just wish I knew a cheap source for those tiny bearings. They really drive the price up! http://prntscr.com/e88r0g
comments.author: csj2k

comments.text: Nice design, especially for being able to glue to make them child-resistant. My kids are old enough not to do this anymore (I hope) so I didn't have that design consideration. I've stuck with the "snap pegs" for simplicity and will also be including a central post and caps in my next thing.

author: csj2k

title: Parametric spider axis coupler in OpenJsCad

description.text:
Here's a spider coupler for coupling two axes. Includes a cutout for a nut and a screw for attachment.  
It's fully parametric, 16 parameters can be edited straight in your web browser.

Try the online version at:
http://joostn.github.com/OpenJsCad/
Scroll down to Examples and choose Parametric Axis Coupler Or download the .jscad file and use the OpenJsCad parser: http://joostn.github.com/OpenJsCad/processfile.html A modern browser is required (for WebGL support). For each side of the coupler the axis diameter, inner depth and outer size can be configured, as well as the size of the tightening srew and nut. The 'spider tolerance' parameter slightly reduces the spider size, allowing the thing to absorb some wobble. OpenJsCad is a javascript and browser based solid 3D CAD tool. For more information see: http://joostn.github.com/OpenJsCad/

title: Iron Man MK2 MK 2 Faceplate Mask interieur

description.text:
17/04/2017 some parts changed for better Fittings
Stand with space for batteries added.

Well I saw Vash's Interieur on therpf.com, but I could not find the files anywhere.
So I decided to create my own. They are not as good as Vash's but I think they will do :-)

https://youtu.be/l4hCRDaj2Zc

The mask is originally made by MIPRESIDENTE. Thingfiles here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:260152
I also putted two needed parts here for download.

One picture shows how the finished version should be.

I just created them to be printed without support. You will need a heat-blower to form them.
I used 3mm LED's for the eyes. The Eyes are printed Transparent and with 100% infill. The connector pins are simple microelectronic pins, which are normally used for arduinos or something similar. I took 12V voltage supply, but just because I got a 12V power pack.

I made 2 just to be printed. ist "part01-11" and "part12-17". You will also Need part 18 and the Stand, but I thought it would be easier to print These parts together. You will also Need to mirror all parts (1-18) one time, toget a full faceplate

What you need for the whole mask:
1xM4 screw with nut.
4x connector Pins (2x male, 2x female)
8x 3mm led
wires
resistor, depending on your supply voltage
power pack
Switch
Some black cloth or foam for the backround
Some old electronicparts to look cool down below in the center :-)
some lether (for the brown parts)

I am not ready with my paint Job. The Surface was sanded by a friend - Sven S. - thanks for that.

Hope you enjoy it. If you got any questions, feel free to ask.

title: Barbie Doll House Bunk Beds - Updated

description.text:
My girl's dollhouse came with only one bed so they asked for bunks. These were designed for Barbie sized dolls which is why they have strange looking proportions!

UPDATE Now with a more rounded bed-head (Head_V2). I've left the original so you can see the changes.

UPDATE Added an alternative version of the beams which use a simple lap joint.

You need to print 4 of each of the 2 beams and two of each of the "slats"

The original beams slot together and connect to sockets in the head and foot of the bunks. You will likely need to file the male parts as they are an intentionally tight fit. The alternative beams are simple lap joints which should be assembled with an adhesive and clamped to set. The "slats" are thin to save on print time and will also need attaching with your choice of adhesive. I glued all joints with two-part epoxy because the kids would soon work them loose otherwise.

Printer:

Anet A8

title: Corner Bracket with Rocker Switch Insert for QU-BD Revolution and RXL 3D Printers

description.text:
The Revolution and RXL do not have a power switch (you need to manually unplug the power cord). This part is intended to fix that shortcoming.  
Designed to be printed without supports - just slide the small snap-in piece into the larger main body piece. Individual STL files provided as well as pre-sliced GCODE that should work reliably well for brand-new RXL/Revolution printers right out of the box.

The rocker switch should fit very snugly. This bracket is designed specifically to fit the RR1 series from E-Switch (http://www.digikey.com/product-detail/en/RR111C1121/EG4772-ND/2116251). Mostly because I happened to have some of those on hand. The part should fit nice and snugly into any bottom corner of the printer - front left or front right is advised though. You will need to alter the wiring so that the Line voltage input to the power supply unit runs through this switch before reaching the power supply's input terminal. If you are not comfortable working on high-voltage electrical wiring, then please find a qualified electrician to help you. High voltage can be deadly!!

title: STEM Teaching Aid --> Foamboard Glider Control Surface Mounts

description.text:
I designed these "H" clips to help teach students about the control surfaces of an airplane.

Using a simple homemade glider from DollarTree foam board, you can attach various angle "H" clips onto the aircraft to simulate ailerons, flaps, elevators, and rudders.

The students can then throw the glider and experience how each surface acts and try out different angle clips to achieve more or less aggressive maneuvers.

remixed_from.title: Tapered thread bowden coupling PC4-M6, PC4-M10

title: Fabrikator Mini v1.5 - Feeder Assembly Bowden Connector Replacement

description.text:
This is to replace(and in my opinion improve) the bowden connection from the feeder assembly on the Fabrikator Mini 1.5 (not sure if it will fit the v1.0 as I don't have one).

I had an issue where the bowden tube kept coming out of the connector. And I see from searches online other people have the issue as well. Some glue and tape might sort it out, but i wanted a cleaner solution :)

The original M6 part from krtektm didn't fit in the Fab Mini screw thread, but when resized to 96% it worked perfectly. So thanks to krtektm for this, I just resized and tested and am posting here so people can find it easier. I printed using Floreon 3D PLA material and it seems to be holding strong.

If you have issues with this falling over when printing, just use a small brim to secure everything and peel it off after.
